Chemical signals

Contrast/Compare

Summarize 
what we know about the

Pheromone: 
its c
hemistry and effect on each caste

,

Pheromone 
and Brood 
Pheromones: Chemistry
/ 
Effect 
on nestmates 
Describe 
Colony odor
/nestmate recognition 
and how it relates to 
robbing 
behavior and recognition of intruders in general 
List 
some beekeeping/Agricultural applications

What are p
heromones 
A 
pheromone is a chemical that transmits information from 
one whole organism to another WITHIN THE SAME 
SPECIES 
In solitary animals, pheromones often transmit mating or 
territorial information, which can be non
-
cooperative 
Bw honey bee and wasp  = just chemical communication but not pheremone

In social insect these chemicals can be used this way but they 
also often serve purely cooperative coordination purposes. 
https://
www.grozingerlab.com
/new
-
page
-
97
 
ensures the dominance of the queen; actively suppress the reproduction of the workers with her pheromones
foragers need to know in advance whether she should go for pollen or nectar
When u have a lot of babies, u need protein(pollen) to make bee bread —> exposed to brood pheromones
Involved in 
communication 
within the hive 
and outside the 
hive

Sting gland
Main Pheromones in Honeybees 
(Outline of the lecture!) 
1
.  
Queen
’s pheromones 
11
-
QMP (Queen Mandibular Pheromone) 
12
-
Other pheromones 
2
. 
Worker pheromones 
21
-
Nasonov pheromone 
22
-
Alarm pheromone 
23
-
Marking resources/Trail pheromone 
3. 
Brood pheromones 
4. 
Nestmate recognition/colony 
odour 
differentiation bw mate and non mate

Pheromones can have a 
Releaser and/or 
a P
rimer 
action 
Releaser 
pheromones release a behavioral 
response that is mediated by the nervous system. 
Releaser pheromones elicit an immediate behavioral 
response. 
Primer 
pheromones alter endocrine, reproductive 
and neurological systems. Changes are not immediate 
but occur in hours to days. 
Many 
social insect pheromones are a blend of many 
components that can act BOTH as releaser and as 
primer pheromones 
-
--
-

Individual 
pheromones can work TOGETHER to 
control a specific behavior or function in the colony 
EXAMPLE 1: maintenance of sterile workers in the hive when a 
healthy queen is present 
With queen 
(queen
-
right) 
Without queen 
(
queenless
) 
Adult Workers 
remain 
sterile as adults 
because of queen 
pheromones 
pervading the nest 
AND 
the presence of 
brood pheromones 
Workers ovaries 
Remove queen = development of 
ovaries in workers

EXAMPLE 2: Queen pheromones 
AND worker’s 
Nasonov 
pheromone 
Are both needed to maintain swarm’s cohesion

www.owensborotimes.com
/features/agriculture/2019/04/understanding
-
honey
-
bees
-
during
-
swarm
-
season/
 
if queen dies, workers 
come back home in the 
original home

Part 1
-
Queen pheromones

1. 
Queen pheromones
-
The “queen signal” is 
chemically complex and emanates from 
multiple glands 
Exocrine glands of the honey bee queen. The pheromone
-
producing 
glands that concur to the formation of the queen signal are highlighted 
in bold. 
Bortolotti 
and Costa, 2014 
5 glands in bold produce queen signal

Many 
of the compounds in the “queen signal” 
have low volatility thus need 
to be transfer
red 
by contact 
Retinue behavior: workers 
surrounding, licking 
Workers then  transfer 
and feeding the queen 
the queen signal 
through trophallaxis 
to the rest of the colony 
-

https://
www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov
/books/NBK200983
/
 
what does queen signal 
do:
-Triggers retinue 
behavior
-helping swarm 
clustering along with 
nasonov
-Attracting drone and 
facilitating mating
-regulating many 
activities:
- guarding of workers
- comb building
- brood feeding
- foraging
-2 negative functions:
- queen doesn’t want 
other queens to be 
reared
- have sterile workers

Summary of 
releaser and primer effects 
of the queen signal (
alone or with other pheromones
) 
1). Releaser effect: 
Retinue 
behavior (to workers) 
Sex 
attraction during mating (to drones) 
Swarm 
stabilization 
(if combined with 
Nasonov 
pheromone from workers) 
2). 
Primer effect: 
Inhibiting of queen rearing 
and swarming 
Simulating 
foraging and brood rearing 
Stimulating 
Hive functions such as comb building, 
food storage, and more 
Contributes 
to worker ovary suppression (
if combined with 
Brood pheromones
)

11
.
 Queen Mandibular Pheromone (QMP) 
Blend of 5 components 
from 
queen mandibular 
gland

gy
-

3.19)

loveridge

QMP.g
if

Role 
of QMP as sexual pheromones: 
Three of the 5 components of QMP 
are believed to play an important role in long
-
range as well 
as short
-
range attraction and/or mating

Role of QMP in swarm cohesion and stabilization (along with 
worker’s Nasonov 
pheromone) 
Queen signal is essential for cohesion of swarm - mostly QMP
What keeps most of those bees just hanging out in close proximity

How could beekeepers 
use the QMP? 
-

-

by

1
.  
Swarm attraction

.

.  
Temporary queen surrogate (ex: 
TempQueen 
strips) 
About 5 dollars 
Per strip

enterance
worker bees expose the

with wings

22
.
 Alarm Pheromone 
At least a dozen compounds mostly from 
the sting apparatus 
(sting gland and 
Koschevnikov 
gland)
, including the high volatility 
compound 
iso
amyl acetate
) 
(aka Isopentyl acetate) (banana/mango 
smell) 
Sting Gland and 
Koschevnikov 
gland 
Smells like banana and mango
produced by the sting gland and also 
the koshevnikov glands

How does the 
use of a smoker 
reduces 
stinging 
by workers? 
-
Share your ideas with your neighbors 
-
Be ready to share with the whole classroom 
using 
PollEverywhere 
3 min

1) hive on fire, busy getting honey and preparing to abandon hive instead of stinging
2) messing up antennae receptors, not efficiently perceiving alarm pheremone
3) masking alarm pheromone, diffused with smoke

Why the smoker 
works is unclear 
and still debated! 
2018 study showed
that smoke did not 
influence the 
probability of sting 
extension but did 
affect whether a 
droplet of venom 
was released by
the stinger 
J. 
Insect Science, 18 (4): 7; 1
-
7 (2018) 
Still same number of pissed off bees, but 
reducing the overall aggressivity of the colony

. 
Marking/
Trail Pheromone

un
-
identified pheromones 
Low 
volatility 
during 
foraging workers mark flower 
with secretions from 
their tarsal and mandibular glands. 
Pheromone oozes 
From tarsal pads

Believed to mark flowers
i was there, no need to get nectar, move on

Part 3
-
Brood pheromones

3
.
 Brood Pheromones 
Produced 
by brood (larvae) 
Low 
volatility (transfer by contact) 
Ratios/concentrations 
of esters change 
as the larvae age 
Blend of 10 
compounds, all 
fatty
acid methyl esters

Effects of Brood Pheromone 
Releaser 
1. 
As cues for brood capping (hey, I am ready to be capped) 
2
.  
Stimulate pollen collection 
Primer 
1. 
Inhibit worker ovary development 
2. 
Stimulate development of hyp
opharyngeal glands 
3. 
Increase royal jelly production 
4. 
Delay foraging and inhibit juvenile hormone levels

Part 4. Nestmate/colony 
odour

Long
-
chained hydrocarbons (HC) coating the exoskeleton are 
a chemical signature that is produced by a combination 
of genotype and physiology 
Within that wax layer within the 
outer shell, u have particular 
hydrocarbons like alkanes 
alkenes
the type/amount related to 
particular genome of the 
individual but also its 
physiology
Used as a fingerprint, u are 
from my hive or not

Each 
colony has an individual 
colony odor 
It
 marks the bees from that colony and is used to recognize 
“residents” versus foreigners 
made 
of queen + diverse odors of the hive such as specific 
nectar/pollen used, type of resin collected, etc. 
absorbed 
in exoskeleton of each resident 
definitely 
effective in identifying non honeybee but mildly 
effective in identifying 
robber bees 
guard bees examine exoskeleton to 
see if they belong to that hive
Most effective for non-honeybees
not as effective for robber bees

Only first 60
-
90 seconds
